title: As a Vladimir main, my only fear if they nerf him is if they Kha'Zix' him
body:
I know that he is strong, he doesn't need nerfs now, but will probably need, after the AP item changes.

However, there are two things that I am afraid of:

1) People still don't learn how to counter Vlad, I've realized that most people just don't know how to capitalize on Vladimir's early weakness.

2) I fear that Riot will do to Vlad the same thing they made to Kha'Zix: nerf him repeatedly until they finally hit what makes him strong, but they won't revert previous nerfs, and Vladimir will be left on dust for a long time until Riot gives him buffs, but those buffs will be very minor.

As another Vlad main, let me barge in and say this. He doesn't have an early weakness. I win almost all my lanes as Vlad because people think I'll be Poppy or Singed, an early farmer, when all I do is harrass them to kingdom come, getting ready to go all ham on lvl6 if their jungler dares showing up.

Vlad is, in my opinion, THE champion with the best lvl1 that plays top. If you know how to farm with your autos, he can save all of his Qs to his opponents. It's not unusual for my lane oponent to be at half health at lvl2. He remains strong throughout the lane, and at lvl9, if he has 4 stacks on his E, he can easily double the jungler. 

Contrary to popular belief, it's not the lvl2 all-iners and lane bullies than win against a vlad. Riven, Irelia, Wukong? I'll just bring them to half health, put a point in W at lvl2 and out-trade them. It's the people with inherit tankiness, who can survive the early levels and scale well into the late game. Sion, Cho'Gath, hell even Nautilus, people who survive and with enough CC to lock down Vlad for when the jungler comes. 

His counters come with intelligent playmaking, jungler support and the ability to lock him down for somebody else to finish the job. This new itemization changes, twice-more if the Abyssal Rework goes through, will push Vlad over the edge, and make him completely unstoppable if he gets ahead, instead of nearly.

His counters are champions with high damage and reliable gap closers, like Riven and Irelia. Sorry, but if the Riven and Irelia players you face are getting taken to half HP by a skill on a 10 second CD, then they're just bad. Also Irelia should have enough sustain with her W + flask that she should be fine until she's strong enough to all in and chunk you.

As a Vlad main I must say: The only champion that gives serious problems to me is Riven, she can all-in me and there is nothing I can do against that. She is resourceless just like Vlad, and while she doesn't have sustain at all, her outstanding damage and CC is too much for Vlad, he will not be able to sustain through that.

The only other champion that used to be as much of a problem as Riven was Fizz, but due to the nerfs, and his loss of Griveous Wounds, he is a lot easier to deal with as Vlad.

Irelia is a skill based matchup. She is only a counter if you aren't experienced, otherwise Irelia is a matchup that is somewhat hard early but can be won, and Vladimir will always outscale her. Unlike Riven, Irelia has a predictable and conditional CC, is mana dependent, and while she has sustain, it isn't enough to outsustain Vlad.

It's going to be hard to pin-point what is going to need to be done after the changes come through. Not just on Vlad, but many champions that are going to benefit heavily from  the AP item changes. 

For Vlad though, I'm not sure what the best option would be. Should they emphasize his healing ability but cut his damage? Should they reduce his ability to heal as effectively and keep his damage? Or should they do something regarding CD's and base stats to keep him down in earlier parts of the game? Thematically I love Vlad, a "blood mage" who sucks the juice out of his opponents and hits them in the face with it. But his damage combined with his healing ability makes him extremely annoying and strong. I love that Vlad can build HP and AP to compliment each other, it's one of my favorite gimmicks in league: {{champion:27}} {{champion:3}} and {{champion:13}} have similar "fun" builds that incorporate different scaling mechanics (less so with Ryze now). 

What I really want Riot to emphasize when they nerf or rework Vlad is to make his build much more... intelligent. Right now, Vlad pretty much goes for high AP builds, and why shouldn't he? He gets a lot of HP for the AP he gets. At 600AP he gets about 850 health if he opts for an HP item as his last item he can have a good chunk of health to work through while he is also dishing out high DPS. 

I remember my first Vlad game ever. Back in the Season 4 preseason/Season 3 postseason. It was an ARAM and he was free that week, so I was going to try him out. I was pretty new at the game and didn't know what I was doing for the most part but I decided to just build against my opponents the best way I knew how. My final build probably looked something like this: {{item:3152}} {{item:3065}} {{item:3143}} {{item:3047}} {{item:3135}} {{item:3157}} . It was a really long match that we were losing for the large portion of the game, but we made a comeback near the lategame as I became nearly unkillable and it allowed me to deal a lot of damage in teamfights. I likely had about 350AP and 3500 health at the end of the game. But what I found is that if teamfights were very extended, my team would come out on top because of my R damage amp (which is INSANITY; teamwide DFG?) and my sustain throughout the teamfights; but if the fight was very short it meant that the enemy team had obliterated us and I was a nonfactor. It was a very memorable game as it was probably the first times I had carried a game, but I think I bought Vlad shortly after that. 

What I want to see out of Vladimir is a way that he can use both aspects of his Passive to boost each other. Right now, the only health items you will see on Vlad is typically a {{item:3065}} or a {{item:3116}} with the rest being full AP items. But I want to go back to what I experienced in my first game as Vladimir. Itemizing primarily against your opponents to make yourself the strongest you possibly can, rather than what it feels like now when the opponent has to itemize AGAINST Vladimir because you need either MR or Grievous Wounds to deal with him as he sustains back whatever you throw at him and he hits like a truck if you have no MR. With the change to WotA in the works, MR is no longer a way to deal with his spell vamp as the healing portion will be at max strength regardless of resistances. 

I think now would be the best time for Riot to get Vlad in a healthy spot though. They can afford to have him more of a tank that deals good damage rather than a high dps mage that can take more than a few hits. Think about it this way. If they cut a lot of his damage in his Q and E, he can still use the heal from WotA without needing penetration. So he can grab{{item:3152}} and {{item:3065}} and use his natural sustain built into his kit in addition to the boosted unhindered heals from his WotA to keep him alive through very extended teamfights. He can then build up more tanky items and just become a super tank that can hit back. Taking Rabadon's wouldn't be that bad either as it gives you AP and HP bonus on top of the 120 AP you get from it that supplements both his heals and his damage. Vladimir is a champion who has low AP ratios on his abilities already (really being saved by their low CD's) so either reducing base damages or his AP ratios a little bit more might incentivise a more hybrid buildpath. 

Those are my thoughts on the matter. Feel free to comment and share your opinion. Later. Peace.

For me, Vlad is a drain tank who can make use of both offensive and defensive items much more freely than other Bruisers. Drain tanks are typically unbalancable, but I feel like late game Vlad works just fine. His kit's play and counterplay are awful, but the need to be in the middle of a fight to deal damage means that there is a lot of decision making to be had, similar to how melee DPS champions have to weigh those decisions.

If I were to do a small scale change, I'd do something like Yasuo where his counterplay starts high but scales down with some stat, maybe Q's range scaling with HP or something. A full rework would be nice though.
